Types of long-term visas for Switzerland (Visa D) If you're staying longer than 90 days, different visa types are available depending on your reason for staying: Work Visa If you have a Swiss job offer, your employer has to sponsor your work visa application. Work permits are subject to quotas and approval by Swiss authorities. Student Visa If you've been accepted into a Swiss university or educational institution, you need to apply for a student visa (D Visa). Requirements include: Proof of admission Evidence of sufficient financial means Health insurance coverage Self-employment / Freelancer Visa Switzerland has strict regulations for self-employed individuals and freelancers. To get a residence permit as a self-employed person, you have to: Show that your business benefits the Swiss economy Prove financial stability and a strong business plan Register your business in Switzerland Digital Nomad Visa Switzerland does not offer a dedicated digital nomad visa, unlike some European countries.
